content.description: The chains are on a ledge you could walk up to if you want to top-rope it. This also means that the rope will drag there, so be careful. My first impression was that you could almost get to the ground from all the bolts, but you can't; it's not nearly that close.
content.location:
This is the left-most route on the west face. It shares the first bolt with

The Wasp

.

content.description: There is no real significant ledge near the top like I first thought. The route is slightly over-hung (not near as much as its neighbors), but there's nothing that looks like it would eat your rope.
content.location:
This route is the next one to the right of

Yellow Jacket

. They share the first bolt.

content.description:
A short, fun climb on

Mineral Fork Tillite

that uses pockets and positive edges to reach and then surmount the large, obvious, rounded cobble two-thirds of the way up. The rock is sharp and gets better the higher you go.

After getting past the cobble trend left on small edges to the anchor.
content.location:
The left-most climb in the dark brownish-green tillite on the lower, southeast-facing part of

The Wasp

.

content.description:
The lower 2/3 (the white area) is really dirty, there are seams and cracks throughout, and many of the places you want to grab feel like the rock is in a socket; dubious rock. Someone should go over it with a pressure washer or something (condition as of Aug. 2006).

If that wasn't enough, the overhang eats rope; the rope will almost always catch in the cracks on the edge. You will spend more time dealing with rope-drag on lead than you will climbing.

...and is the misspelling of "Gnat" intentional?
content.location: This is the route on the south face. Like the rest of the routes, you can clip the first bolt by coming in from uphill, then going back downhill to begin climbing if it makes you nervous (but, really, it's all about the same).

content.description: Fun little crack, if a bit loose in places. The crux is probably turning the roof near the top. But there are good holds everywhere, so it's not too bad. After turning the roof, clip the last bolt on Magic Helmet (the bolted 5.10 to the right) and finish on Magic Helmet's anchors.
content.protection: A few small to medium sized pieces. One bolt. Uses the chains on Magic Helmet.
content.location: The crack in the corner to the left of Magic Helmet.

content.description: Follow two bolts up to the roof. Find the jugs at the lip and clip the bolt above the lip. The next move is the crux: a deadpoint lunge to a big jug. Once you pull the move, get your feet up and find a key horizontal flake/knob for your left hand to steady yourself, clip the bolt, and keep climbing on moderate terrain past one more bolt to the top.
content.location: Climbs the right side of the roof on The Throne. Directly to the right of Magic Helmet.

climbs.name: Magic Helmet
climbs.fa: Tristan Higbee, Christian Burrell, Brett Anderson

content.description: The second star is for turning the roof which is pretty neat. The rest of the climb is pretty mellow. Crux is probably the reach to a hole above the lip of the roof. The reach is a bit farther than you would like. But you can clip the bolt from below the roof.
content.location: right up the middle of the wall through the center of the roof.

content.description:
The whole thing is pretty much overhang-climbing. The lower, white rock is not as messy as

Super Knat

, but be careful.

The rope will drag over the last overhang, so either use webbing, or self-rappel off.
content.location:
Climb the arete between

The Wasp

and

Super Knat

.

content.description:
Fun, balancy climbing on glacially-deposited

Mineral Fork Tillite

. Start just to the left of a left-facing corner and head up and slightly left. Use a couple of pockets and good edges, along with an undercling or two.

Some fun movement getting past the second and third bolts that requires committing yourself a bit farther left and away from some comforting holds than your mind would like.
content.location:
The left-most climb in the dark brownish-green tillite on the lower, southeast-facing part of

The Wasp

. Shares the top two bolts and anchor with

Glacial Recession

to the left.

content.description: Pumpy steep climbing on sharp pockets and edges. Stick clip the first bolt for safety.
content.location:
Climbs between

Glacial Obsession

and

Tillite Delight

.
